poem:
Title: The Invisible Stethoscope

In the morning streets,
the frayed ribbon of strike,
roars in unrequited toil:
a doctor, cloaked in austerity,
pays the price.

Lean, the negotiations,
pale beneath a foggy sky.
The stethoscope – silent, waiting,
oscillates between hope and surrender.

An offering, they say, but
knowledge wears no collar,
Its cadre deserves its fruit,
A trimmed wick amidst the dark.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Junior doctors’ pay disputes can and should be avoided | Letter It is the government’s failure to make a satisfactory offer after 15 years of pay restraint that has fuelled ongoing strike action by junior doctors (Junior doctors in England plan ballot for more strikes, 8 January). That this position should have been reached at all also reflects the inadequacy, as currently operated, of the independent pay review process, initiated in the 1960s to prevent". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
